msItem.textLang: Primitive Irish written in ogham script

supportDesc.condition: A large irregularly shaped cave divided into two aisles by a rock buttress. There are opposing rows of small holes cut into the rock about 1 1/2-2m above the present floor which have been interpreted as sockets for small bars of wood (Forsyth 1996, 94). The walls of the cave are full of natural fissures but the south aisle of the cave also exhibits copious carvings and graffiti, including two ogham inscriptions (S-BUT-001 - S-BUT-002), an ogham text written in pigment (S-BUT-003), and what appears to be another ogham inscription but may be natural fissures (S-BUT-X01).

layoutDesc.layout: The south aisle of the cave is decorated with carvings of horses, deer, and concentric circles. The buttress bears a large and a small cross and the figure of a man with raised hands holding a curved object above his head. Towards the entrance, on the south wall there are two triangles and on the north wall of the south aisle there is a group of serpent-like spirals and four ogham inscriptions (Forsyth 1996, 94-5). The inscriptions are carved on the left-hand wall of the cave, about 2m above the present floor. The Blackwaterfoot 3 inscription is parallel to and to the right of the Blackwaterfoot 1 inscription (S-BUT-001).

handDesc.handNote: The inscription is not cut into the rock but seems to be scribed in pencil or some kind of ink (Forsyth 1996, 95). Jackson attributes this pigment-based ogham inscription to a recent vandal (1973, 95).

history.provenance: Located in a sandstone cliff about 3km north of Blackwaterfoot are a series of caves of which the King's Cave at Drumadoon (Druim an DÃºin 'ridge of the fort') is the largest. The walls of the cave exhibit carvings which span from perhaps the Bronze Age to the present day. The animal and geometric carvings have been known since at least the end of the seventeenth century, but the presence of ogham was not noticed until about 1968 (Forsyth 1996, 94). However, in 1921 L M Mann recorded that he cleaned parts of the walls and roof 'thoroughly' and he identified identified oghams adjoining the serpents on the NW wall (Fisher 2001, 160). Although Mann noted the presence of this painted ogham text in a letter to G Baldwin Brown, no publication resulted from Brown's proposed visit (Fisher 2001, 160). As a result, these oghams went unnoticed until Kenneth Steer brought the Blackwaterfoot 1 ogham inscription to Kenneth Jackson's attention and arranged a trip to the cave to examine, measure, and draw the Blackwaterfoot 1 inscription in September 1971 (Forsyth 1996, 94). Jackson published the Blackwaterfoot 1 ogham inscription (S-BUT-001) in 1973 and also mentioned this painted ogham text Blackwaterfoot 3 (S-BUT-003). Jackson did not mention Blackwaterfoot 4 (S-BUT-X01), which is the ogham-like marking to the left of Blackwaterfoot 1, or the Blackwaterfoot 2 ogham inscription (Forsyth 1996, 95). Though only a short distance away from Blackwaterfoot 1, the Blackwaterfoot 2 ogham inscription was not discovered until 1992 by Ian Fisher of the RCAHMS while conducting further survey work on the cave (Forsyth 1996, 94).
